importance: This paper is significant as it tackles the critical problem of **catastrophic forgetting** in continual learning, a major hurdle in developing truly adaptable AI systems.  The proposed **Automated Continual Learning (ACL)** offers a novel approach to overcome this issue, providing a significant advancement in the field. By focusing on meta-learning, it offers an innovative solution applicable to other continual learning challenges, potentially paving the way for more robust and flexible AI applications.
summary: AI systems trained using Automated Continual Learning (ACL) meta-learn their own in-context continual learning algorithms, significantly outperforming traditional methods by mitigating catastrophic forgetting.
takeaways: ACL effectively addresses catastrophic forgetting in continual learning.
ACL-trained algorithms outperform existing hand-crafted and meta-continual learning methods.
ACL showcases the potential and limitations of in-context continual learning.
tldr:
Continual learning (CL) in neural networks faces the challenge of catastrophic forgetting (CF), where learning new tasks causes the network to forget previously learned ones.  Existing CL methods often rely on manually crafted techniques to mitigate CF, which are often task-specific and lack adaptability.  This paper explores the limitations of these approaches and proposes a novel solution.
The proposed method, Automated Continual Learning (ACL), uses self-referential neural networks to meta-learn their own continual learning algorithms.  The process involves encoding continual learning desiderata into meta-learning objectives, effectively solving the problem of in-context catastrophic forgetting.  Experiments show ACL outperforming existing methods on standard benchmarks and demonstrating effective continual learning across diverse tasks.  The paper also explores the limitations of in-context continual learning, paving the way for future research.
